class="css-103l8m3"><div class="css-1u5onbp epjyd6m1"><div class="css-165eim7 ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/dani-blum" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Dani Blum" class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/dani-blum" class="last-byline css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">Dani Blum</a></p></div></div></div><div data-testid="reading-time-module"><div class="css-3xqm5e"><time class="css-1g7pp1u e16638kd0" dateTime="2024-08-22T13:32:39-04:00">Aug. 22, 2024</time></div></div><div class="css-1ru5sog"><a class="css-1isxx8x" href="https://www.nytimes.com/es/2024/08/23/espanol/nuevas-vacunas-covid.html" data-version="es" title="Read in Spanish">Leer en español</a></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-0"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The Food and Drug Administration <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/22/health/covid-booster-vaccines.html" title="">approved updated Covid-19 vaccines</a> on Thursday, paving the way for the shots to soon land in pharmacies, doctors’ offices and health centers. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said it will recommend that adults and children six months and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">older get updated vaccines</a>. Here’s what to know.</p><h2 class="css-1u37br4 eoo0vm40" id="link-2326425b">How are the new shots different?</h2><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The F.D.A. approved one vaccine from Pfizer and one from Moderna. Representatives from the drug companies said that their shots were ready to ship immediately after approval.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Both vaccines target KP.2, a strain of the coronavirus that started to spread widely this spring. The variants that are most prevalent in the United States right now are very similar to KP.2, and so the vaccines should protect against them.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="RelatedLinksBlock-1"><div data-testid="lazy-loader"></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-1"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“When the match is very good, as we anticipate it would be with the current circulating strains, you get actual protection from infection for several months,” said Dr. Paul Sax, the clinical director of the division of infectious diseases at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-3"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-2"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The vaccine that rolled out last fall, by contrast, was geared at an older variant that has since petered out.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The biotechnology company Novavax is waiting for the F.D.A. to authorize its retooled vaccine, which will target JN.1, a variant that is also close to the strains circulating widely now.</p><h2 class="css-1u37br4 eoo0vm40" id="link-26f4323d">What if I just got a vaccine?</h2><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">If you received a dose of the older vaccine this summer, you may not be able to get an updated vaccine immediately — the shots need to be spread out.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">People who are at high risk of developing severe disease should talk with a health care provider about the ideal interval between vaccines, said Fikadu Tafesse, a virologist at Oregon Health & Science University.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-5"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-3"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-1u37br4 eoo0vm40" id="link-65eb0257">What if I just had Covid?</h2><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">If you’re one of the many Americans who was infected during the summer, you may want to wait a few months to get a new shot. Rushing out to get one right after you were ill won’t give you much of an added benefit, because you already have strong protection, said Aubree Gordon, an infectious disease epidemiologist at the University of Michigan. The C.D.C. has previously said that people can wait <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/downloads/covid-19-immunization-schedule-ages-6months-older.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">three months</a> after a Covid infection to get a vaccine.</p><h2 class="css-1u37br4 eoo0vm40" id="link-4e83653f">How fast does protection kick in?</h2><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">It takes around a week or two after getting vaccinated for antibodies to rev up and defend against the virus. Antibodies peak about a month after vaccination, Dr. Gordon said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Once you are vaccinated, you have a lower risk of infection for at least several weeks, said Dr. Peter Chin-Hong, an infectious disease specialist at the University of California, San Francisco. “It might even be longer than that,” he said, because the vaccines are so closely matched to the dominant variants that are currently circulating.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">And the vaccines will provide protection against the worst outcomes from Covid — developing severe disease, getting hospitalized and dying — for months.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span></p><h2 class="css-1u37br4 eoo0vm40" id="link-2a9b2e2d">When should I get vaccinated?</h2><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">People who are at highest risk for severe disease, including those who are 65 and older, people who are immunocompromised and those with underlying medical conditions, should get the updated vaccines as soon as they are available, Dr. Sax said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-7"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-4"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“There’s a lot circulating in the community now — that would help protect them,” he said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">People who are not at high risk may want to wait until October, Dr. Chin-Hong said, both to gain protection heading into the winter and holiday gatherings, and so that they can get flu shots at the same time.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Convenience trumps everything,” he said.</p><h2 class="css-1u37br4 eoo0vm40" id="link-2eded470">Can I get it for free?</h2><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Many private insurance plans, along with Medicare and Medicaid, cover the cost of Covid shots. And children can receive free vaccines through <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines-for-children/about/index.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">a federal program</a>. The C.D.C.’s <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/06/well/cdc-covid-vaccines-free-program.html" title="">Bridge Access Program</a>, which has provided about 1.5 million free Covid shots to uninsured and underinsured people, will not be renewed for this year. But Dr. Demetre Daskalakis, director of the C.D.C.’s National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, said that the agency had found $62 million in unused vaccine contract funding that would be sent to state and local immunization programs to help cover the cost of shots.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div></section><div class="authorPageLinkClass overrideLinkStyles" href=https://www.nytimes.com/by/dani-blum>More about Dani Blum</a></span></p></div></div></div><div class="css-lojhqv">A version of this article appears the match is very good, as we anticipate it would be with the current circulating strains, you get actual protection from infection for several months,” said Dr. Paul Sax, the clinical director of the division of infectious diseases at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":4},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The vaccine that rolled out last fall, by contrast, was geared at an older variant that has since petered out."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":5},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The biotechnology company Novavax is waiting for the F.D.A. to authorize its retooled vaccine, which will target JN.1, a variant that is also close to the strains circulating widely now."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":6},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"What if I just got a vaccine?"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"If you received a dose of the older vaccine this summer, you may not be able to get an updated vaccine immediately — the shots need to be spread out."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":7},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"People who are at high risk of developing severe disease should talk with a health care provider about the ideal interval between vaccines, said Fikadu Tafesse, a virologist at Oregon Health & Science University."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":8},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"What if I just had Covid?"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"If you’re one of the many Americans who was infected during the summer, you may want to wait a few months to get a new shot. Rushing out to get one right after you were ill won’t give you much of an added benefit, because you already have strong protection, said Aubree Gordon, an infectious disease epidemiologist at the University of Michigan. The C.D.C. has previously said that people can wait "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cdc.gov\u002Fvaccines\u002Fcovid-19\u002Fdownloads\u002Fcovid-19-immunization-schedule-ages-6months-older.pdf"}],"text":"three months"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" after a Covid infection to get a vaccine."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":9},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"How fast does protection kick in?"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"It takes around a week or two after getting vaccinated for antibodies to rev up and defend against the virus. Antibodies peak about a month after vaccination, Dr. Gordon said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":10},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Once you are vaccinated, you have a lower risk of infection for at least several weeks, said Dr. Peter Chin-Hong, an infectious disease specialist at the University of California, San Francisco. “It might even be longer than that,” he said, because the vaccines are so closely matched to the dominant variants that are currently circulating."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":11},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"And the vaccines will provide protection against the worst outcomes from Covid — developing severe disease, getting hospitalized and dying — for months.  "}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":12},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"When should I get vaccinated?"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"People who are at highest risk for severe disease, including those who are 65 and older, people who are immunocompromised and those with underlying medical conditions, should get the updated vaccines as soon as they are available, Dr. Sax said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":13},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“There’s a lot circulating in the community now — that would help protect them,” he said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"People who are not at high risk may want to wait until October, Dr. Chin-Hong said, both to gain protection heading into the winter and holiday gatherings, and so that they can get flu shots at the same time."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":14},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“Convenience trumps everything,” he said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Can I get it for free?"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Many private insurance plans, along with Medicare and Medicaid, cover the cost of Covid shots. readabilityObject.title: New Covid Vaccines: What to Know about Efficacy, Access and Cost
readabilityObject.content:
Advertisement

SKIP ADVERTISEMENT

New Covid Vaccines Are Coming. Here’s What to Know.

We asked experts about the right time to get a shot, and how long protection will last.

The Food and Drug Administration approved updated Covid-19 vaccines on Thursday, paving the way for the shots to soon land in pharmacies, doctors’ offices and health centers. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said it will recommend that adults and children six months and older get updated vaccines. Here’s what to know.

How are the new shots different?

The F.D.A. approved one vaccine from Pfizer and one from Moderna. Representatives from the drug companies said that their shots were ready to ship immediately after approval.

Both vaccines target KP.2, a strain of the coronavirus that started to spread widely this spring. The variants that are most prevalent in the United States right now are very similar to KP.2, and so the vaccines should protect against them.

“When the match is very good, as we anticipate it would be with the current circulating strains, you get actual protection from infection for several months,” said Dr. Paul Sax, the clinical director of the division of infectious diseases at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston.

The vaccine that rolled out last fall, by contrast, was geared at an older variant that has since petered out.

The biotechnology company Novavax is waiting for the F.D.A. to authorize its retooled vaccine, which will target JN.1, a variant that is also close to the strains circulating widely now.

What if I just got a vaccine?

If you received a dose of the older vaccine this summer, you may not be able to get an updated vaccine immediately — the shots need to be spread out.

People who are at high risk of developing severe disease should talk with a health care provider about the ideal interval between vaccines, said Fikadu Tafesse, a virologist at Oregon Health & Science University.

What if I just had Covid?

If you’re one of the many Americans who was infected during the summer, you may want to wait a few months to get a new shot. Rushing out to get one right after you were ill won’t give you much of an added benefit, because you already have strong protection, said Aubree Gordon, an infectious disease epidemiologist at the University of Michigan. The C.D.C. has previously said that people can wait three months after a Covid infection to get a vaccine.

How fast does protection kick in?

It takes around a week or two after getting vaccinated for antibodies to rev up and defend against the virus. Antibodies peak about a month after vaccination, Dr. Gordon said.

Once you are vaccinated, you have a lower risk of infection for at least several weeks, said Dr. Peter Chin-Hong, an infectious disease specialist at the University of California, San Francisco. “It might even be longer than that,” he said, because the vaccines are so closely matched to the dominant variants that are currently circulating.

And the vaccines will provide protection against the worst outcomes from Covid — developing severe disease, getting hospitalized and dying — for months.

When should I get vaccinated?

People who are at highest risk for severe disease, including those who are 65 and older, people who are immunocompromised and those with underlying medical conditions, should get the updated vaccines as soon as they are available, Dr. Sax said.

“There’s a lot circulating in the community now — that would help protect them,” he said.

People who are not at high risk may want to wait until October, Dr. Chin-Hong said, both to gain protection heading into the winter and holiday gatherings, and so that they can get flu shots at the same time.

“Convenience trumps everything,” he said.

Can I get it for free?

Many private insurance plans, along with Medicare and Medicaid, cover the cost of Covid shots. And children can receive free vaccines through a federal program. The C.D.C.’s Bridge Access Program, which has provided about 1.5 million free Covid shots to uninsured and underinsured people, will not be renewed for this year. But Dr. Demetre Daskalakis, director of the C.D.C.’s National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases, said that the agency had found $62 million in unused vaccine contract funding that would be sent to state and local immunization programs to help cover the cost of shots.

A version of this article appears in print on  , Section

A

, Page

18

of the New York edition

with the headline:

What to Know About Updates To the Vaccine For Covid-19. Order Reprints | Today’s Paper | Subscribe
